questions.question_text: A network administrator needs to create a network for 4,000 devices while conserving address space. Which of the following subnet masks should be used on this network?

discussion.content:
One subnet has 256 hosts in total (254 usable). 4000 hosts (4096) is 4096:256=16 full subnets or classes of IP. 
256-16=240, so 255.255.240.0
on your subnetting chart, this would be a /20, in your 3rd octet obviously

questions.question_text: A network technician needs to administer the desktop of a Linux-based workstation remotely on the local network. Which of the following remote access methods should the network technician use?

discussion.content: They don't include the word "desktop" for no reason here folks. There's also no mention of a secure requirement and the remote administration would be over the local LAN further supporting that a secure mechanism isn't necessarily needed in this a case (is secure still best practice even when on the LAN, yes, but no mention of it being a requirement here). If the question said "remotely administer a Linux desktop via a secure method", SSH would be it, but it says "administer THE desktop". "THE" desktop = GUI which = VNC. Just my opinion.

It’s not VNC because it works only if we install a VNC server on Linux beforehand. 
“If you need to remote into a GUI-enabled Linux server, your fastest, cheapest option is VNC. There are instances when you need to not only log into a remote Linux machine but gain access to the full desktop of said machine. When you need to do such a thing, you're going to need the help of a VNC server”
Google
Just a guess here, but if they wanted the answer to be VNC they would have probably mentioned something about GUI. Since they didn't, I guess we go with the de facto standard of SSH??

comments.content: administer- manage and be responsible for the running of

discussion.content: SSH is the correct answer since it asked "to administer" and you'll likely have putty installed on the Windows pc and you know the Linux IP address.
I believe it's VNC (D) because it specifically says we are trying to "administer the desktop" of a workstation. RDP would be the other choice but this is a Linux workstation so it can't be that.
I believe it is SSH, I do this daily through Putty using SSH if I cannot console in.
Going w VNC

I am going to break it down right quick :D...The key phrase in this question is "point-to-point connection." This means that 2 nodes must communicate. The answer is /30 with a total of 4 IP addresses where only 2 IP addresses can be used. I hope this provides some clarity.
I may miss read the question, we need two host, hence /30 is the correct answer.
C. /30.... IS the correct answer.

/30 means that 30 bits is allotted to the Network portion which leaves us to just 2 host bits.
Now since the question requires a point to point connection and with efficiency meaning no excess address. Since 2 bits are left in the host portion 2^2 = 4, 1 will be for the Network ID, 1 for broadcast ID and 2 left for the usable addresses that will cater the point to point connection.

Always subtract one from the total value of the 0s. Since it's /30, it means the 1&2 are available as hosts. 
1+2 = 3 hosts
3-1 = 2 hosts

Further clarification for anyone who has never set this up: Interfact on router a 9which connects to interface on router b) needs to have a common subnet with each other. /30 has 4 IP's, two usable. Put on IP on router A's interface, and the other usable IP on router B's interface. Configure each routers interface to have the same network and broadcast IP. If you have a larger subnet, the other IP's would go to waste.

a /30 would give you a total of 62 subnet and 2 host per each subnet. to me this is wring. I'd say /25 will give you two subnet and 126 host per each subnet. Since this is a point to point, you need only two subnets. Hence, /25 looks the correct answer.

comments.content: You need a broadcast and netid, so /30 is the correct answer, which gives you 4

discussion.content: because a /30 network can only have 2 hosts there for in a point to point connection you only need 2 host IP addresses.
can someone please explain why C is the correct answer. thank you.

comments.content:
point to point connection means 2 IPs per subnet. no. of IPs=2^z-2=2, 2^2=4, so, z=2 and z+b= 8,
 then, b=6 where b is the no. of borrowed bits

questions.question_text: A technician is setting up a branch office on a point-to-point connection. Which of the following IP network blocks is the MOST efficient use of IP address space for the router connections between the two sites?

discussion.content: process of elimination

It's one of MeassureUp question.
But basically if u have 2 routers or more between your PC and DHCP Server you need IP helper.

You can implement an IP Helper address to forward Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) broadcasts on to their appropriate destination. In this way, you can implement a single DHCP server as one management point where you can check the leases for any device on your network and manage all the IP subnets on your network.
Seems 99% of the time when IP Helper is included in a question. IP Helper is the answer lol.
I never heard of an "IP helper" until just now. Whattup?
Not A?

questions.question_text: Devices on a network will need to obtain DHCP leases from a server on a different network. Which of the following must the engineer implement for DHCP to forward requests to the designated server?

A network administrator it concerned about the management traffic between a machine and the corporate router. Which of the following protocols should the administrator use to prevent a security breach?

discussion.content: Management traffic is the keyword.
